verses.text: Manasseh was twelve years old when he became king, and he reigned fifty-five years in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Opening verse; retains original structure. Manasseh's long reign is historically noted.

verses.text: He did what was evil in the sight of the LORD, copying the detestable practices of the nations the LORD had driven out before the Israelites.
verses.comment: Restates covenant language regarding Israel's practices vs. nations dispossessed.

verses.text: He rebuilt the high places that his father Hezekiah had destroyed. He set up altars to the Baals, made Asherah poles, and bowed down to all the host of heaven and served them.
verses.comment: Literal rendering of 'host of heaven' (celestial bodies).

verses.text: He built altars in the house of the LORD, where the LORD had said, "My Name will be in Jerusalem forever."
verses.comment: Direct reference to God's Name and chosen dwelling.

verses.text: He built altars for all the host of heaven in both courtyards of the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: Specifies two courts per original Hebrew structure.

verses.text: He made his sons pass through the fire in the Valley of Ben Hinnom, practiced soothsaying, divination, and witchcraft, and consulted mediums and spiritists. He did much evil in the LORD's sight and provoked Him to anger.
verses.comment: Worded to reflect the seriousness of prohibited pagan practices.

verses.text: He set a carved image, the idol he had made, in God's house, of which God had said to David and Solomon his son, "In this house, and in Jerusalem, which I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel, I will put My Name forever."
verses.comment: Captures the contrast between the idol and God's promise.

verses.text: I will never again remove the Israelites from the land I appointed for your fathers, if only they will be careful to do all I have commanded them through Moses— all the laws, statutes, and judgments."
verses.comment: Conditional promise language preserved; based on obedience.

verses.text: But Manasseh led Judah and the people of Jerusalem astray, so that they did more evil than the nations the LORD had destroyed before the Israelites.
verses.comment: Highlights Judah's sin exceeding that of previous nations.

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Manasseh and his people, but they paid no attention.
verses.comment: Simple summary of God's warning and their refusal to heed.

verses.text: So the LORD brought upon them the commanders of the army of the king of Assyria, who captured Manasseh with hooks, bound him with bronze shackles, and took him to Babylon.
verses.comment: 'Hooks' translates from 'nose hooks' or 'rings,' as used in Assyrian captivity.

verses.text: In his distress, he sought the favor of the LORD his God and humbled himself greatly before the God of his fathers.
verses.comment: 'Sought favor' for 'entreated'; remains literal.

verses.text: He prayed to Him, and God was moved by his plea, listened to his request, and brought him back to Jerusalem to his kingdom. Then Manasseh knew that the LORD is God.
verses.comment: Major theme: repentance and restoration.

verses.text: Afterward he built an outer wall for the city of David, west of Gihon in the valley, to the entrance of the Fish Gate; he encircled the Ophel, and raised it up to a very great height. He also put military commanders in all the fortified cities of Judah.
verses.comment: Identifies locations; 'Ophel' left untranslated per standard practice.

verses.text: He removed the foreign gods and the idol from the house of the LORD, and all the altars he had built on the hill of the house of the LORD and in Jerusalem, and threw them outside the city.
verses.comment: Action verbs aligned with Hebrew consecutive structure.

verses.text: He rebuilt the altar of the LORD and offered on it sacrifices of peace offerings and thank offerings, and he commanded Judah to serve the LORD, the God of Israel.
verses.comment: Sacrifice terms preserved in accordance with Levitical law.

verses.text: Nevertheless, the people still sacrificed on the high places, but only to the LORD their God.
verses.comment: Acknowledges partial reform not entirely according to temple law.

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Manasseh, his prayer to his God, and the words of the seers who spoke to him in the name of the LORD, the God of Israel, are written among the records of the kings of Israel.
verses.comment: Emphasizes that other details are available in the (now lost) historical annals.

verses.text: His prayer and how God was moved by him, and all his sin and unfaithfulness, as well as the sites where he built high places, set up Asherah poles and images before he humbled himself—these are written among the records of the seers.
verses.comment: 'Records of the seers' ('Hozai') is preserved per original note.

verses.text: So Manasseh rested with his fathers, and they buried him in his own house. And his son Amon became king in his place.
verses.comment: 'Rested with his fathers' is literal for 'died.'

verses.text: Amon was twenty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned two years in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Introduction of Amon; matches parallel account in Kings.

verses.text: He did what was evil in the sight of the LORD, as his father Manasseh had done. Amon sacrificed to all the carved images that his father Manasseh had made, and served them.
verses.comment: Repeated phrasing is preserved; emphasis on generational sin.

verses.text: But he did not humble himself before the LORD as his father Manasseh had humbled himself; instead, Amon only multiplied his guilt.
verses.comment: Stresses contrast in response to God between Manasseh and Amon.

verses.text: And his servants conspired against him and put him to death in his own house.
verses.comment: Follows criminal conspiracy as in original text.

verses.text: But the people of the land struck down all who had conspired against King Amon, and the people made his son Josiah king in his place.
verses.comment: Transition to Josiah as king; captures popular reaction and support.
